node.text:
From a very early age, African-American civil rights icon and #UnitedNations leader, Ralph Bunche understood the pain and peril of racism.

Yet Bunche turned those experiences into a catalyst for change on the international stage, pursuing a legendary career as one of the most senior diplomatic officials of his time. 

From walking side-by-side with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., to working for peace as a UN mediator in Palestine, watch and learn more about the Nobel Prize Laureate. 

#FightRacism

node.title: Hero for Justice on the World's Stage

node.text:
"Because of climate change we are seeing even more intense storms, rising sea levels and many deaths. But we don’t have to accept this – we can act - and we must act as a matter of justice."

Environmentalist Sunita Narain explains why it's important that all of us #ActNow to achieve the goals of the #ParisAgreement. 

"Every country, rich or poor, is exposed to extreme weather. We need to build better and more resilient infrastructure – from electricity grids to roads, bridges and buildings. All these approaches are set out in the Paris Climate Agreement – adopted by nearly 200 countries. We can do it – we must do it – and we must act quickly."

From recycling to using less energy and water to opting for public transport, each and every one of us can take little steps in our everyday lives that can have a big impact. Tell us in the comments what you are doing to protect our planet.

#ClimateAction #GlobalGoals

node.text:
"We don’t have to choose between using energy and protecting the planet."

@unep Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee explains the role sustainable energy plays in building a better future for all. 
 
"Imagine a world where every job is based on clean, renewable energy – and where wind and solar are even more abundant. And where energy is affordable and reliable – and available to everyone. This might sound like a fantasy – but it’s achievable and we know how to get there."

The #ParisAgreement on the climate emergency is our roadmap for moving to a low-carbon economy and achieving a sustainable future. Since this international #ClimateAction treaty opened for signature 5 years ago, almost 200 countries have signed on to tackle the climate crisis together to limit global warming to protect people and planet.

 #GlobalGoals #ActNow

node.text:
Cities are major contributors to the climate crisis, but also an important hub for #ClimateAction.

@UNEP Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee explains what a green future for cities could look like & how the #ParisAgreement can help us get there.

node.text: Meet @unep Young Champion of the Earth Nzambi Matee. She's a Kenyan engineer taking #ClimateAction and helping to #BeatPlasticPollution by recycling plastic waste into building materials.

node.text:
"My warmest wishes to everyone celebrating #EidAlFitr," #UnitedNations Secretary-General @antonioguterres said on Wednesday.

"I was delighted to mark the end of Ramadan with Asia El-Sayeed Ali, a Yemeni health worker helping malnourished children and mothers in a @worldfoodprogramme-supported nutrition clinic.

Asia personifies core values of Ramadan: compassion and empathy. Her resilience in the face of the devastating conflict in Yemen, as well as her life-saving work in support of people in desperate need have moved me greatly.

As #Ramadan comes to an end, let us continue drawing inspiration from its many lessons of solidarity that are celebrated during this Holy Month."

Regram: @antonioguterres

node.text:
Regram: @antonioguterres

Young people are the most affected by the climate decisions taken today. Their ideas, voices and actions are crucial to deliver meaningful and ambitious #ClimateAction for all.

@pcopaloma and @mahery_loha are two inspiring climate activists who exemplify the leadership and commitment of young people worldwide to address the most challenging problems we face today.

I'm grateful for our discussion and their insights on how to achieve the meaningful participation of youth, women and indigenous peoples as we tackle the climate crisis.

#ActNow #GlobalGoals

node.text:
@unep Goodwill Ambassador @aidanrgallagher describes how the #ParisAgreement can help us create a world free from the threats of the climate crisis. 

"This is personal for me," he explains. "I don’t want to choke on the air I breathe, or see wildfires burning out of control. So let’s keep working together. And you too can protect what is left and repair what has been damaged."

On Thursday's #EarthDay, @antonioguterres will be joining the U.S. Leaders’ Summit on Climate to reiterate his call for urgent #ClimateAction. 

"The Paris Agreement is our pact with our children, grandchildren & the whole human family," said the Secretary-General. 

"The climate crisis is the race of our lifetimes. We must go much further, and much faster."

#GenerationRestoration #ForNature

node.text: On Monday's International Day of Human Space Flight, @europeanspaceagency astronaut @thom_astro became the newest @fao Goodwill Ambassador. He will use his voice and unique perspective from space to advocate for #ClimateAction and to help reduce hunger.

node.title: French astronaut Thomas Pesquet becomes newest @fao Goodwill Ambassador

node.text:
All children have the right to a happy and healthy childhood, free from discrimination and full of love and acceptance. And acceptance begins at home. Every child should grow up in safe, loving and nurturing environment.

No child should suffer because of who they are. All children deserve protection and equal rights. Let's see kids the way they see themselves.

On Wednesday's International Transgender Day of Visibility, join @unaidsglobal in calling for the rights of transgender children to be protected.

#TransDayOfVisibility #SeeMeAsIAm

node.text:
Six years since the start of the conflict, millions of Yemenis are in need of humanitarian assistance. Over four million are displaced within the country. 

Our colleagues from UNHCR, the #UnitedNations Refugees Agency, are in #Yemen providing aid, but they cannot do it alone. 

Please click the link in the @refugees' bio to help. 

#YemenCantWait

node.text:
Maya (@ghazalmia) fled Damascus, #Syria at age 16 and overcame numerous barriers to become the world’s first female Syrian refugee pilot. 

Check out her inspiring story!

#WithRefugees

node.title: Meet Maya Ghazal, the newest @refugees Goodwill Ambassador

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 13, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of bicycle, street and brick wall.

node.text:
A biker passes fragments of the #BerlinWall in #Germany. 

Friday marks 60 years since construction began on the wall, which fell in 1989. 

"While the wall has been long torn down, artificial divisions continue to be built in too many places," said #UnitedNations Secretary-General @antonioguterres on the anniversary. "Let's never lose sight of our power to dismantle them and our ability to create a better world."

📷: UN Social Media / @missfotos 

 #GlobalGoals #StandUp4HumanRights

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and sitting.

node.text:
19-year-old Houleye is a bright young woman from a small village in #Mauritania.

When she participated in a digital skills vocational training course supported by the World Food Programme (WFP), she took her very first photo, which unveiled an untapped talent. 

The first time Houleye saw her photo of a woman preparing lunch for school children, she was incredibly happy and proud to have taken such an authentic and emblematic photo in her village.

Houleye is among 20 women who participated in the storytellers training course, which has helped them share images of resilience and strength in their communities.

Regram: @worldfoodprogramme 

#GlobalGoals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 12, 2021. May be an image of 5 people, people sitting, people standing and indoor.

node.text:
Regram @antonioguterres:

Young people are on the frontlines of the fight to build an inclusive, fair and sustainable world for all.

With drive, creativity and commitment, they are tackling some of the world's most pressing issues, from food security to biodiversity loss, gender equality and education and skills development.

I urge everyone to guarantee young people a seat at the table as we work to create a better future.

I will do all I can to be an ally, and help ensure sure they are engaged, included and understood. 

📸: Pakistan, 2020 (UN Photo/Mark Garten), Switzerland, 2020 (UN Photo/Jean Marc Ferré), USA, 2017 (UN Photo/Kim Haughton), New Zealand, 2019 (UN Photo/Mark Garten)

#YouthDay

node.text:
An elephant roams peacefully in Mikumi National Park in #Tanzania.

Elephants are vital to our ecosystem, yet, their population is declining by almost 8% every year. At the turn of the twentieth century, there were 10 million elephants in Africa. But decades of poaching and habitat loss have taken a heavy toll on these smart, highly social creatures. Today just 415,000 remain.

Wednesday's #WorldElephantDay is an opportunity to honour these iconic animals, to spread awareness about the critical threats they are facing and support solutions that will help ensure their survival.

Here are some actions you can take to help protect elephants:
- Get information about the status of wildlife and wildlife products.
- Don’t invest in ivory as a commodity.
- Support companies that demonstrate sustainable supply chains and environmentally responsible policies.
- Spread the word and encourage others to get better informed.

📸: UN Photo

#GlobalGoals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 11, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
UN peacekeepers protect civilians, prevent the spread of violence and help countries around the world achieve lasting peace.

These brave women and men come from different countries, cultures and backgrounds, but share a common purpose: to improve lives and to further peace, even amid the challenges posed by the #COVID19 pandemic.

👉 Scroll through to see photos of peacekeepers working with the @unpeacekeeping missions in Mali (MINUSMA), Lebanon (UNIFIL), South Sudan (UNMISS) and the Democratic Republic of the Congo (MONUSCO).

📸: @unifil_official, @un_minusma, @unmissmedia, @monusco_officiel

#ServingForPeace #GlobalGoals #A4P

node.text:
12-year-old Mohamed from #Mauritania smiles at the camera during a study break.

The young student was preparing for his middle school entrance exam when schools closed due to the #COVID19 pandemic last year. "Fortunately, soon after, my classmates and I received textbooks, supplies and solar-powered radios. At first it was a little strange to learn at home, but I quickly got used to it," he explains. 

Each day, Mohamed would listen to the lessons broadcasted on his radio and then recite them to his parents. Thanks to his hard work and a remote learning programme supported by @unicef, Mohamed was able to continue his studies, pass his exams and get accepted into middle school. 

With many students living in places with limited or no internet access, radio became an indispensable tool for learning. Throughout the pandemic, UNICEF has been working with partners to develop educational radio programmes to ensure children can keep up with their studies.

Regram: @unicef I 📸: UNICEF/UN0495421/UN0495429/UN0495428/Pouget

#ForEveryChild #GlobalGoals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 10, 2021. May be an image of big cat and outdoors.

node.text:
A lion watches over his territory in #Kenya.

Tuesday is #WorldLionDay.

Less than a century ago, there were more than 200,000 lions in Africa. Today, there are only about 20,000 left. In the last two decades alone, lion populations have dropped by more than 40%. 

The unrestricted exploitation of wildlife has led to the disappearance of many animal species, threatening Earth's biological diversity and upsetting the ecological balance.

Here are some actions you can take to help protect big cats:

- Get informed about the status of wildlife and wildlife products.
- Support companies that demonstrate sustainable supply chains and environmentally responsible policies.
- Spread the word and encourage others to get better informed.

📸: UN Photo

#GlobalGoals

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'CODE RED FOR HUMANITY'.

node.text:
Regram: @antonioguterres 

Today’s @ipcc climate report is a code red for humanity. 

The evidence is irrefutable: greenhouse gas emissions are choking our planet & placing billions of people in danger.

Global heating is affecting every region on Earth, with many of the changes becoming irreversible.

The internationally agreed threshold of 1.5°C global warming is perilously close.

We must step up our efforts and act urgently & decisively to keep the 1.5°C target alive.

#ClimateAction #ActNow

node.text:
Throwback to August 2017 when Grand Chief Wilton Littlechild, a Cree Chief from #Canada, opened an #IndigenousDay event at UN Headquarters in #NYC. 

Indigenous peoples make up less than 5% of the world's population, but speak 60% of the world's languages and represent 5,000 different cultures.

Monday's International Day of the World's Indigenous Peoples is an opportunity to celebrate indigenous peoples everywhere & their contributions to our world. 

"Let us show true solidarity by working to end the grievous inequalities of indigenous peoples worldwide, to fully recognize the abuse they have endured, and to celebrate their knowledge and wisdom," said #UnitedNations Secretary-General @antonioguterres. 

📷: UN Photo/Kim Haughton

#WeAreIndigenous #GlobalGoals #StandUp4HumanRights

node.text:
From a very early age, African-American civil rights icon and #UnitedNations leader, Ralph Bunche understood the pain and peril of racism.

Yet Bunche turned those experiences into a catalyst for change on the international stage, pursuing a legendary career as one of the most senior diplomatic officials of his time. 

From walking side-by-side with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., to working for peace as a UN mediator in Palestine, watch and learn more about the Nobel Prize Laureate. 

#FightRacism

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by United Nations on August 08, 2021. May be a closeup of 1 person and cat.

node.text:
For many people, fleeing the conflict in #Syria also meant leaving their pets behind. 

In response, Mohammad Alaa Aljaleel created a shelter for abandoned cats and many other animals he rescued from the rubble. Now, more than 1,000 cats have found shelter in his Ernesto Cat Sanctuary.

"Since the people and my friends left the country, the cats have become my friends," says Mohammad. "I will stay with you no matter what."

This #InternationalCatDay, join us in showing Mohammad your support and celebrating our fine feline friends who have provided many of us comfort during difficult times, including during the #COVID19 pandemic. 

Do you have a cat? If so, tell us your kitty's name in the comments.

Regram: @refugees | 📷: Anas Alkharboutli/DPA

#WithRefugees

node.text:
12-year-old Purity proudly presents one of the vegetables she grew in a school garden in #Zambia.

By tending to the garden, students learn about practices like hydrophonics, a fast and soilless cultivation technique that enables plant growth throughout the year. 

''Before the hydroponics garden, we would only eat beans and maize. Now we have greens and eggplant," explains Purity. Thanks to the garden, the school has been able to diversify and improve school meals for its 200 students.

In Zambia, extreme weather and the impacts of the climate crisis have disrupted food systems, slowing down food production, distribution and consumption. With increased prices, schools face difficulties in providing students with nutritious meals.

Around the world, including amid the #COVID19 pandemic, the World Food Programme (WFP) has continued to support sustainable school meal programmes, helping millions of children to stay healthy and focused on their education. 

Regram: @worldfoodprogramme I 📸: WFP / Andy Higgins

#ZeroHunger #GlobalGoals
